content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-027-09-A
|Item_parent=Prevention of foetal risks: infection, drugs, toxic substances, irradiation
|Item_parent_short=Prevention of foetal risks: infection, drugs, toxic substances, irradiation
|Rank=A
|Title=Knowing the definition of maternal-fetal measles
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Alexandre Vivanti, Philippe Deruelle
|Order=9}}
The risk of transmission is possible at the end of pregnancy and may result in neonatal congenital measles, but this is exceptional (given vaccination coverage).

question.question: What is the primary risk associated with maternal-fetal measles transmission?
question.option_a: It primarily occurs in the first trimester and causes severe birth defects.
question.option_b: It is highly common and results in neonatal congenital measles in most cases.
question.option_c: It is possible at the end of pregnancy and may result in neonatal congenital measles, but this is exceptional.
question.option_d: It only affects the mother and has no impact on the fetus.
